sn22.123:4.1: At one time Venerable Sāriputta and Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita were staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana.
sn22.123:4.2: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita came out of solitude, went to Venerable Sāriputta,
sn22.123:4.3: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn22.123:5.1: “Reverend Sāriputta, what things should an educated mendicant carefully focus on?”
sn22.123:5.2: “An educated mendicant should carefully focus on these five grasping aggregates as impermanent … as not-self.
sn22.123:5.6: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
sn22.123:5.8: An educated mendicant should carefully focus on these five grasping aggregates as impermanent … as not-self.
sn22.123:5.10: It’s possible that an educated mendicant who regards the five grasping aggregates in this way will realize the fruit of stream-entry.”
sn22.123:6.1: “But Reverend Sāriputta, what things should an mendicant stream-enterer carefully focus on?”
sn22.123:6.2: “A mendicant stream-enterer should carefully focus on these five grasping aggregates as impermanent … as not-self.
sn22.123:6.4: It’s possible that a mendicant stream-enterer who regards the five grasping aggregates in this way will realize the fruit of once-return.” …
sn22.123:6.7: “It’s possible that a mendicant once-returner who regards the five grasping aggregates in this way will realize the fruit of non-return.” …
sn22.123:6.8: “It’s possible that a mendicant non-returner who regards the five grasping aggregates in this way will realize the fruit of perfection.” …
sn22.123:7.1: “But Reverend Sāriputta, what things should a perfected one carefully focus on?”
sn22.123:7.2: “Reverend Koṭṭhita, a perfected one should carefully focus on the five grasping aggregates as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as an abscess, as a dart, as misery, as an affliction, as alien, as falling apart, as empty, as not-self.
sn22.123:7.3: A perfected one has nothing more to do, and nothing that needs improvement.
sn22.123:7.4: Still, these things, when developed and cultivated, lead to blissful meditation in the present life, and also to mindfulness and situational awareness.”
